editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: The Execution of THE Popi≈øh Lord, &c.

div.p:
IN mo≈øt Ca≈øes it is ob≈øervrd, that Traytors ≈øeldom depart in Silence or quiet to their Graves, ≈øome untimely Death or other ≈øtill awaits their Impieties, and tho≈øe that dig Pits for others, mo≈øt commonly fall into the ≈øame them≈øelves; for 'tis certain, that tho≈øe whom the effects of ≈øuch Trea≈øon mo≈øt may profit, will in no wi≈øe after tru≈øt the Traytor, lea≈øt he upon ≈øome di≈øta≈øt ≈øhould Propagate, or at lea≈øt endeavour the like again≈øt him when opportunity lies fair; For in Ancient
Times it has been noted, that Traytors have been looked upon as Infernal Pe≈øts, even by tho≈øe they have Perpetrated their Villanies and Ignominious Trea≈øons to advance: Nay, could not the ≈øhort ≈øight of Humane Rea≈øon dive into their Pernicious ways, the God that views the Secrets of all hearts, would by one means or other lay them open to the World; ≈øo that each di≈øcerning Soul might fatham the depth of their dire policies, ≈øo often is their Wi≈ødom turned into Fooli≈øhne≈øs: and when they think their Plots mo≈øt ≈øecure, they are neare≈øt di≈øcovery; as has been in the mo≈øt of their late Con≈øpiracies and intended Eva≈øions. But to come nearer to the particulars of this late Lord Vi≈øcount Stafford, of who≈øe de≈øerved downfall we are to inform the world.

HE being formerly but a-mean Gentleman, but Marrying to the Counte≈øs of Stafford, his Maje≈øty was graciou≈øly plea≈øed to Confer the Titles and Honours of that Family upon him; for which, Viper-like, he endeavoured to de≈øtroy what was the onely fountain of his Greatne≈øs and Pro≈øperity; by engaging a Damnable and Helli≈øh Plot, again≈øt the Life of the King and Prote≈øtant Government; which ju≈øt as it was going to break in upon us, was by the will of Divine Providence, made manife≈øt to the whole Nation; broached even by tho≈øe that them≈øelves had given the greate≈øt Confidence to; for all the Evidence that have as yet been In≈øtrumental in the Di≈øcovery, were tho≈øe whom
they had imployed for the promoting the De≈øign, ≈øo weak is the piercing Intelect of Humane rea≈øon compared with that Divine. Full Sixteen Years, according to Evidence, has this Device been mannaged, not only by the whole Conclave of Popi≈øh Cardinals, the Pope, and the greate≈øt part of his Clergy, but by a great part, if not all the Popi≈øh Nobility of England, Scotland, and Ireland, who≈øe E≈øtates have been con≈øumed and much impaired in the Management of the ≈øame, as hoping to be doubly repayed, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing the Lands and Wealths of Hereticks, as was al≈øo proved again≈øt this Lord. True it is, they looked for a plentiful Harve≈øt becau≈øe their De≈øign was to fatten the Earth with Prote≈øtant Blood; nor did the Ma≈ø≈øacre they de≈øigned, portend any le≈øs: All above Ten years Old had Peri≈øhed by pre≈øcription, had not the Mercy of an Infinite God interpo≈øed to have ≈øtopped the Torrent of their Rage, which like a Flood was ≈øwel'd even with the Banks, and ju≈øt prepared to overflow Church and State; but in what they thought them≈øelves mo≈øt ≈øecure, they were found mo≈øt Weak, for by Murthering Sir Edmundbury Godfrey, to prevent a farther Di≈øcovery, they laid their Wicked Projects open to the view of all; whereupon many of the Plotting Traytors were Detected, and among≈øt the re≈øt, this Vi≈øcount continuing by a Commitment of Parliament a long ≈øpace Pri≈øoner in the Tower, where no ways were left unpracticed to gain his Freedom, but
his nor any the re≈øt could prevail, for on the Thirtieth of November he was brought in a Barge from his Impri≈øonment, to We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall, where the Great Court of Ju≈øtice was Erected for his Tryal, the Tower Ax being born before him: His Looks at the beginning of his Tryal were Blith and Chearful, as not fearing any ill Con≈øequence, but when he heard the Witne≈ø≈øes ≈øwear, in number Three, That he would have Hired ≈øome or all of them, to Murther the King, and that the Prote≈øtants ≈øhould be Ma≈ø≈øacred, and that he was in the Con≈øpiracy to bring in a Foraign Power, and to E≈øtabli≈øh Popery, he began to Tremble and look pale. It's true, he produced many Witne≈ø≈øes, but they could not ≈øpeak any thing to the purpo≈øe in his behalf, their Affirmation con≈øi≈øted only in Circum≈øtances, and rather perjudiced his Cau≈øe then farther'd it; In fine, he was found Guilty by his ‚Ä¢ eers, the Lords Temporal a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, and according to his ju≈øt De≈øerts, received Sentence of death; being conveyed back to the Tower, where he continued till this day, preparing for his Latter end, yet by no means for≈øaking tho≈øe prepo≈øterous Super≈øtitions that had brought ≈øuch Ruine on his Head.

In the morning he was brought out of the Tower, attended by a Guard of Parti≈øans and Souldiers, the Tower Hamlets making a Lane for him to
pa≈øs to the Scaffold, prepared for his Execution; great part of the City Train'd-bands being in Arms. When he came to the Scaffold he was helped up by two or three Attendants; and being mounted looked very wi≈øhfully, as loath (no doubt) to dye: for ≈øure it is, how ever men can ≈ølight death at a di≈øtance, yet when it comes near them, and is certain, it ≈øtrikes a Con≈øternation, e≈øpecially where the Brea≈øt is charged with Guilt and diabolick Trea≈øons.

After he had ≈øpoke to ≈øome of his Friends, and made ≈øeveral prayers to him≈øelf, for the mo≈øt part holding in his hand, as it is ≈øaid, his Beads and Crucifix, he kneeled down to try how the Block fitted, then having a Cap on, he after ≈øome con≈øideration, gave the Executioner a ≈øign to ≈øtrike, which he did, and with one inforced ≈øtroke, divided the Head from the body, both of them containing motion of Life for a while, but the body longe≈øt.

After Execution his Head and body were wraped up in a convenient Garment, or put in a Coffin, and carried back to be di≈øpo≈øed of as his Maje≈øty ≈øhall think fit. Thus was he Rewarded for his Trea≈øonable practices, and received the Merits due to ≈øuch Helli≈øh intents; ≈øo that although Ju≈øtice doth oftentimes delay, yet at la≈øt it will ≈øtrike home, to the de≈øtroying from off the face of the
earth, all ≈øuch as wilfully Sin again≈øt their own Con≈øciences, to gratifie Ambition or Revenge, again≈øt ≈øuch who never offered them the lea≈øt Indignity: For as notonly this Lord, but many others did confe≈øs that the King could no ways be found fault withal, but was a good and ju≈øt Prince, but being a Heretick and not for their turns, he mu≈øt be made away. So the Devil, out of envy to their Happine≈øs, plotted the Downfal of our fir≈øt Parents in Paradice, and ever ≈øince wicked men have envy to tho≈øe that are Upright.
